Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A: Development of an Animal Tracking Tag for Biological Research: Refractive Index for Rapid Georeferenced Salinity Measurements over a Wide Dynamic Range
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to SRI International to develop small tags which will be attached to marine animals and acquire data from the ocean environment. The first prototype tags will be sized for medium to large animals, such as penguins, turtles, and sharks. These data tags will record information central to understanding animal migration. In more general applications, the increased amount of data obtained by the tags will provide valuable information to scientists and policymakers to help understand the complex properties and changes in the ocean and other aquatic environments, thus aiding conservation efforts. Important areas for study include estuarine environments, where rapid profiling can record dynamic conditions, and low and high salinity areas such as choked lagoons, coastal isolated lakes, and subglacial lakes. The data will enhance our ability to understand seasonal variations, changes caused by human populations and activities, and global climate change. This project will support three undergraduate student internships (one chemical engineer and two biologists). The project will also include a lesson plan on ocean salinity measurements for a local high school with a high percentage of underrepresented groups to increase interest in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) education, and to encourage young students to consider multidisciplinary careers in engineering and the sciences with environmental conservation in mind.

Sensors in the innovative tags will measure water temperature, depth, and salinity (the amount of dissolved salts), which are interrelated indicators of ecosystem health. The data produced will be geo-referenced; that is, the tag will provide a location of the collected information. These tags will differ from current commercial devices by measuring salinity as a function of the optical properties of the water (the refractive index) by detecting and recording changes in the interaction of light with the sensor (patent pending). The major advantages of the optical measurement include fast operation, wide dynamic range, and cost effectiveness for the attainable resolution. The parameters collected by the tag will provide valuable information about the marine environment that can be correlated to locations where specific animals travel to satisfy their basic food and reproduction needs, and will provide insight into habitat changes linked to declining marine populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a novel animal tag that provides rapid salinity measurements via an optical technique and has the resolution and accuracy needed for biological research. In this work, SRI International built on its refractive index-based (RI-based) technology to develop and test an animal tag that addresses the deficiencies of currently available tags and accurately measures conductivity, temperature, and depth (CTD). SRI worked with Connectsix LLC and Dr. Kate Mansfield, director of the University of Central Florida's (UCF's) Marine Turtle Research Group (MTRG), to design, build, and test a prototype animal tag sized for large sea turtles, such as adult loggerheads, and other large marine animals.   

The major objective of this project was to design and build a RI-based animal tag that would provide researchers with georeferenced water salinity data to investigate this parameter with respect to turtle behaviors such as foraging and migration. Our proposed optical method measures the refractive index of the water, which is directly related to the water density and salinity. The tag will allow turtles (or other marine animals) to act as bio-loggers, providing fine-scale data on the physical surroundings these animals encounter. These data may be correlated with other sensor data or used to refine remote sensing-based environmental models. Understanding the environmental parameters that affect the animal's behavior will aid conservation efforts.

To accomplish this objective over the course of the project, we approached development in a step-wise process, starting with evaluating the optical configuration and electronics, building and refining our prototype, testing and characterizing the tag in the laboratory with respect to salinity and temperature, and then testing it for the first time in the field. The prototype tag is 4 in. in diameter by 2 in. high and contains the RI and salinity measurements, as well as temperature and pressure. The tag also has GPS, ZigBee communications, and internal data storage capabilities. From the laboratory calibrations, we obtained an overall resolvable sensitivity of 0.002 ppt salinity and 2 x 10-6 RI at a constant temperature of 21 °C. Continued testing and refinement is needed to develop a robust calibration that accounts for the effects of salinity and temperature on the measurement.   

In addition to characterization in the laboratory, we tested the tag for the first time in the lagoon at Sebastian Inlet State Park, FL using a setup that allowed us to submerge the tag in a crate (no turtles were tagged in this test). While the tag size is suitable for large adult loggerhead turtles, critical discussions with the MTRG team and a visit to their East Coast base of operations helped us elucidate the changes we need to make to ensure the sensor is more robust and will survive attachment on the turtles as well as to refine it for use in smaller juvenile turtles. The knowledge we gained regarding the environment of the nesting female sea turtles, their nests, the hatchlings' journey to the ocean, and the goals of conservation procedures have provided us with critical information for use in developing a turtle tag that will be robust and useful in studying juvenile and adult sea turtles.

This project provided the funding for an undergraduate internship for a student in the Chemical Engineering program at the University of South Florida. He helped us build a setup for calibrating the sensor, performed salinity and refractive index calibrations, and researched and documented commercial instruments and competitive technology. In addition, this project provided him with experience working in a multidisciplinary, corporate environment.

We also visited Lakewood High School, a local school in St. Petersburg, FL as visiting scientists and presented three instructional sessions during which we talked about the need for accurate ocean measurements and related technology in the context of global climate change. We talked about the conservation of marine species and how the sensor we are developing will provide insights for biologists and marine scientists regarding the trajectories of migrating turtles. The classroom time also included a laboratory exercise we developed to give students an experience working in groups to determine the salinity of several salt solutions using a handheld refractometer. Between the three classes, a total of 60 students participated. We intend to publish this material to share it with other educators.
